editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The doubtful heir. A tragicomedy, as it was acted at the private house in Blackfriars, written by James Shirley.
London, printed for Humphrey Robinson at the three pigeons, and Humphrey Moseley at the prince's arms in st. Paul's churchyard. 1652.

div.head: To the most worthily honoured sir Edmund Bowyer.
div.p:
Many years are vanished, and a period, not only of the scene, but more considerable revolutions have passed, since I had the happiness to be first known to you. I read excellent characters of you, when you writ but a small letter, and though my observations, like seeds, were not cherished (By the fault of time) to a maturity, yet they begat in me such great respect to your person, then budding with honour, and expectation, that now after so long absence, I find them not extinguished; and howsoever at the first complexion, I may appear bold, in this hasty interruption, yet your candour will be so far in my
defence, that I have presumed thus, rather to let you know I can still honour you, than unsatisfy myself, by neglecting the first opportunity of presenting my service. Sir, it is a piece, which perhaps you have seen in the active representment; the estimation it gained from thence, will be short of that grace it shall derive from your acceptance, by which you will show, how still you dare retain your nobleness, and by renewing your smile upon me, encourage me to write myself

lg.l: All that the prologue comes for, is to say,
Our author did not calculate this play
For this meridian; the Bankside, he knows,
Are far more skilful at the ebbs and flows
Of water, than of wit, he did not mean
For the elevation of your poles, this scene.
No shows, no dance, and what you most delight in,
Grave understanders, here's no target fighting
Upon the stage, all work for cutler's barred,
No bawdry, nor no ballets; this goes hard;
But language clean, and what affects you not,
Without impossibilities the plot;
No clown, no squibs, no devil in't; o now
You squirrels that want nuts, what will you do?
Pray do not crack the benches; and we may
Hereafter fit your palates with a play:
But you that can contract yourselves, and sit
As you were now in the Blackfriars pit;
And will not deaf us, with lewd noise and tongues,
Because we have no heart to break our lungs,
Will pardon our vast stage, and not disgrace
This play, meant for your persons, not the place.

div.head: Act. i.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This turn was not expected, prince Leonario
Is much perplexed.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.l: I cannot blame his highness,
So near an expectation of a blessing,
To be thus crossed.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The day of marriage set,
With the applausive vote of both the kingdoms,
By an unlooked for war to be put of,
Would vex a royal spleen.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: 'Tis but deferred.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I do not like the hope on't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I pity
The princely lover, worthy (Without blemish
To the excelling virtues of the Queen)
Of as much goodness as her sex contains,
So noble in his nature, active, bountiful
Discreet, and valiant, if we may believe
What his young fame proffers to every knowledge.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This character is not flattery and yet
The Queen our mistress is not lost in this
Just praise of him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I have no thought so impious,
My duty never taught me to commend
But to obey, her virgin sweetness makes me
Her just admirer but when I observe
Her prudent manage of the state, a strength
Would become many years, her pious laws,
But that without example, made to advance
Her sex's chastity, I forget all
Beside worth praise, though every least of her
Desert would ask a volume. 'tis his excellence.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There's one not sorry for these wars.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: 'Tis his
Profession; soldiers batten in a tempest.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And he deserves employment; yet I think
He'll never purchase with his pay.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be confident;
Your worth will plead alone; the Queen expects me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your highness' humble creature; — so, there's hope yet
After a time of ease, and surfeit, we
May cure ourselves by letting others blood.
My noble lords.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: 'Morrow captain, you look blithe, and bright.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll put my sword to scouring that shall shine.
I thank heaven my prayers are heard.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What prayers?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: That honest men may cut knaves throats, and bid
Defiance to the hangman; musk and civet
Have too long stifled us, there's no recovery
Without the smell of gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But captain —

sp.speaker: 1 C.
sp.l: 'Tis he, we must not lose him,

sp.speaker: 2 c.
sp.l: He has credit with the lords it seems.

sp.speaker: 1 c.
sp.l: He has spied us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My honest friends, welcome to court. My lords
Pray grace these honest gentlemen, they will
Deserve to kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: 1 c.
sp.l: Our business
Is to you captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Do you think what these brace of baboons come for?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: By this day for money, moneys that I owe 'em.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I ha' mpved your suit gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 c.
sp.l: What suit?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Touching the masque. Which you two in the name
Of the whole city, offered to present
At the town charges to congratulate
The Queen's intended marriage; I know
This egg was long a hatching and expected,
But that your heads could not agree, they being
Of several sizes, some upon the shoulders
Of your long-winded officers, whose purse
Was made of the leather with their conscience.

sp.speaker: 1 Ci.
sp.l: Does he talk to us of a masque?

sp.speaker: 2 Ci.
sp.l: Good captain put your masque off, and give us.
The money that you owe us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Was't not meant nobly?
But you my good lords know how much
The Queen and prince are sorry, that so rare
A precedent of their duty should not be
Upon record; this villainous war distracts
All civil mirth, but you will be remembered.

sp.speaker: 1 Ci.
sp.l: We know not what you mean, we have no antics
In agitation; if your captainship
Will pay your debts, so; there is law and courses
To be taken, and you will find that justice
Can deal sir with the sword as well as balance.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The pups talk philosophy; nay then
I must be plain, would I could 'tice 'em to
A little treason, they'll ne'er hang for felony.
Why, whither do you think I am going now?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: We care not whither so you pay us first.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Let their own father's swing, so they have money.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: May be you are going to the wars.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes mongrels,
To fight for your chamlet faces, while you stay at home
And catch the cramp with telling money,
Putting your guts to pension every day,
And roots, until the wind cry out again you,
And with your belching backwards stifle men
That walk the street, until the air be purged;
Must we eat bullets without butter. Whelps?
Have our throats cut, or drop like sheep by th' hundred,
Of the rot, to buy your peace, you boding screech-owls?
And ha' your consciences so course a nap
To ask money of us?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: You had the conscience
To take up our commodities.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Reason good;
Should I go naked leeches?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: No but there is reason
That you should pay good captain for your warmth.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Pay you? for what? for clothes, such things as these?
Your tribe is bound to keep us.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes, and desire us to accept your wares,
To recompense our sufferings; 'tis we,
'Tis we that keep your worship's warm and living,
By marching, fasting, fighting, and a thousand
Dangers, (You o'er grown moths) you that love gold,
And won't take an angel sent from heaven
Unless you weigh him, you that spend the day
In looking o'er your debt — book, and at night
Can lap and lecher in your feather beds.
Then snort, and dream of fourscore in the hundred,
Afraid of nothing but the gout, or what
Is a more just reward for your hard hearts
The stone, which puts you to the charge of physic
To make you piss out your last usurer's gallon,
Or of a surgeon to cut you for
The pebbles, which (If you survive incision)
You keep in penny boxes, like dear relics,
And show your friends, when you intend to visit 'em.
And beg a dinner.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Let not passion
Make you too much abuse their quality;
The city does contain brave fellows captain,
As generous, as bountiful, discreet,
And valiant too, as any boast themselves
In court or camp.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I grant you my good lord,
And honour all the noble souls within it,
But these are walking sicknesses, not citizens;
Two such prodigious things with crooked consciences,
Though young yet old in usury —

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: All this captain
Won't pay us our money, which we must
Have, or petition for to your disgrace.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Well since there is no remedy, will you take
These two noblemen's words for what I owe you?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Withal our hearts.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That bargain is to make.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Good captain, at this time you may excuse us,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why, do your lordships think I'd let you surfer,
Come, you're my honourable friends; pass, pass
Your word, I'll pay the money; hang 'em dotterels
I'll not be beholding to 'em.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We had rather you should good captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: No, — come hither capons
Will money content you; shall I walk the street
Without a head ache, with your bawling for
The debt when I ha' paid you?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: 'Tis but reason.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll fetch you money presently — you may follow
If you please, but these noblemen shall see
And witness what I pay you, I'll not trust
Your memorandums.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Withal our heart's sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: We desire no more.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll wait on you again.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fortune de la guerre.
My lord Leandro? what papers that
He so intentively peruses?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I like it and could willingly allow
The change; the Queen grows mighty in her spirit,
And this match with the prince would swell her state
Too much; my lords.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We are yours.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: See what dangerous papers have been scattered
To wound the title of our royal mistress;
My servant brought me this; our enemy
Who calls himself prince Ferdinand would fain
Have us believe him cousin to the Queen,
She an usurper of his crown.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: We all know him dead.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I'm sure I did attend his funeral.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I think I waited too.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: This paper says he was conveyed away,
And so escaped his uncle's cruelty,
To whose protection he was left an infant;
He dying, we translated our obedience
To his daughter, now our Queen.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Here's an impostor.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Heaven aid the innocent say I; he has
Valentia's aid and comes not to invite
But force a resignation; I wish things
Were calm again.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Prince Leonario if she prosper not,
Is like to be a loser too.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: For him
It matters not, we have more to think on now,
Than love and compliment.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I thought he would be general
'Gainst this pretended Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: What else?
Her sweet heart, that gives Cupid in his crest.
Alas! there needs no art, nor strength of war
To advance her cause. Justice will fight for her
I'th' clouds, and victory sent from heaven, without
Her soldier's sweat, will gloriously descend
To crown his head with laurel.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: May it prove so.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: I could say things would stagger your belief,
But I forgotten the Queen sent for me; to
You both a servant —

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I do not like my lord Leandro's winding,
He has been faithful.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Always honourable. The Queen.

div.stage: Enter Queen, Leonario, captain, Leandro, Violinda, attendants, ladies, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I take this as the greatest honour madam
You could confer; my name is young in war,
But my affection to your royal person,
Armed with the virtue of your cause, shall make me
Do something worth your name.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Twas your request.
Nor could we place our chief command, but where
'Tis equalled with your interest in us
And your own merit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sure my stars did mean
This way to make you know, how much my heart
Dares in your service; and if Ferdinand,
For so he calls himself, possess a soul
Above the vulgar making, we shall spare
The blood of many, and conclude the war
In single opposition.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: With your highness' pardon,
It not becomes you should engage your person,
And so great a cause so dangerously;
It will be too much honour to th' impostor,
And in the supposition of the world,
A strength to his pretence, to bring your birth
So low, to humble both yourself and fortunes
To his unworthy level, a thing grown
Up in the night, a meteor hanging in
The air, prodigiously, fed with vapour, and
Black influence, ambitious to deceive
The world, and challenge kindred with the stars;
It is too great a venture sir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Since there must be a war
Let the armies meet in battle there's more hope
After the worst to reinforce and prosper,
Than when the kingdoms put upon one stake,
And one man's chance to assure it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I allow
Your counsel lords; but have more argument
Convincing me, not to run such a hazard
Of what must make Olivia rich hereafter;
A kingdom's loss may be repaired, but your
Life made a sacrifice to tyrant war.
May find a welcome to the other shades,
But no tears can invite you back, to share.
Or grief, or joy with me; I'll have no duel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis a command, and my obedience
Shall meet it, though I fear 'twill be a sin
To be too careful of myself, but I
Shall still remember I am your soldier.
And this considered shall not make me rash,
But wisely teach me to deserve this title
Which lives but in your honour.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I'll pray for you,
And not so much for what concerns the state,
As what your merit hath already gained
Upon my heart.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Blessings upon 'em both,
A curse upon these wars, that spoil their mirth.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: My lord Leandro.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There's your commission captain, I suppose
You have found ways to empty your exchequer.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My bags are not brimful my lord. I have
Defalked, and made an ebb for wine, and women,
And other things that keep poor men alive
To do their country service.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Please you walk
With this gentleman captain, he shall pay you
Five hundred pieces that I owe you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Me, your grace owes me nothing,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I could not pay the debt in better time sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Umh! I will take the money, and allow the miracle.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Did you observe the prince's nobleness?
Although the act become him. Yet the manner
Takes me especially, heaven preserve the captain
From being mad.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I prosper in your vote,
But shall I madam, if that power, which crowns
With victory guides me with fair success
In this your war, and triumph smile upon us,
Shall I at my return have that reward
My soul next heaven affects? shall no delay
(Colder than frost to lover's blood,) afflict
My expectation of our marriage?
Although to doubt this be a sin, yet where
The ambition is so just, I shall but right
My heart, to have it oft assured, nor can
It make your eye less rich in smiles, when 'tis
Only my love encourages me to make
The busy harmless question.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: It does please me,
Nor can you ask so often, as I have
A cheerfulness to answer, that I love you,
And have propounded nothing dearer to me,
Than that which perfects chaste affection,
And chains two hearts; the priest with sadness will
Expect you safe again, but from this war
When you return, he shall not in his register
Of lovers, find one, with more wing hath met
The bosom of her friend, than glad Olivia
To make one soul with you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have enough,
And thirst for action in the field, from whence
I will bring harvest home, or leave myself,
Happy in life or death to do you service.

div.stage: Ex. Queen, Leon. Lean. ladies, attendants.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Well, I'm afraid if Hymen should set up
His tapers now, they would not last to light
His priest, at their return to say his office.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Hope fairly.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I allow his spirit, but
The prince hath not been practised in
The school of war, where stratagems prevail
Above all personal resolution.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: He cannot want fit counsel to direct
His early valour, besides
Ferdinand by computation as young as he
sp.stage: Enter captain, two citizens, and a soldier.
sp.l: May poise the scale. See, the captain.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: We always thought you noble, and we hope
You'll take no offence, that our occasions
Prevailed above our modesty.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I know
You two are very modest; well I'm glad
I am furnished for you: my good lords I must
Entreat you to be witnesses of what money
I pay these gentlemen, that have trusted me.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: And will again; command our shops.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: No, sit there, and starve,
Or if you like it better take a swing
At your own sign post.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Good words captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: They expect good money, and both good are too much.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: We always loved you.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: And do so still most virtuously.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It does appear,

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: And you shall find us ready —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll make but one fair motion, it will be
Sufficient trial of your honesty;
I have five hundred pounds, you see me tell it,
Faith make it up a thousand 'twixt you both
Till I come back, you will be aldermen.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Ne'er a whit the sooner.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Alas sir, if it were at another time —

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Hereafter, upon good occasion you shall find —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You both i'th' pillory, for selling copper
Lace by a wrong name; well there's no remedy,
I'll keep my word; the money's ready for you.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: You are noble captain.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: May you kill all the Queen's enemies.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You would not scape,
That cousin her liege people every day, then.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: This payment captain will come most seasonably.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: And do us as much good, as you had given us
The sum twice told, another time.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Before
These noblemen, have you such want
As you profess? you have no wives nor children.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: I protest upon my credit, I am to pay
This day two hundred pound, or be endangered
To an arrest.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: And I must go to prison
If before sunset —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Then 'twill do you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Both. Cit.
sp.l: Above expression.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Here's twelve pence a piece for you you're fit men
To serve the Queen:

sp.speaker: Both Cit.
sp.l: How captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why in the wars, choose either pike or musket,
You shall have that favour.

sp.speaker: Both Cit.
sp.l: We are both undone.

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.l: Ha, ha, but will you use 'em so?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Have they not ready money? why d'ye stare?
No thanks for my protection?

sp.speaker: Both cat.
sp.l: Protection?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Did you not protest you should to prison else?
Why you unthankful sons of false light, sergeant
Take 'em to their rendezvous

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Captain, a word — we are content —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'm glad on't, why d'ye stay then.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: To abate half our money.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: All, all good captain, he shall have all, rather
Than be sent a soldiering; d'ye know what 'tis?
'Tis no artillery garden, where you come off
With as you were.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This was his project.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Umh '. You will forgive me both your debts?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: And pray heaven to forgive you too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My lords, bear witness,
These two would bribe me to abuse the Queen
And the present service, is this less than treason?

sp.speaker: Both Cit.
sp.l: Oh. Er. nay, nay captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: There are not two more able men i'th' army,
I mean for bulk; ram me into a cannon
If you shall buy yourselves with your estates
From this employment; il not cousin you,
Your money is good debt still, you may live,
And ask me for't again, and I may pay you.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: But shall they serve indeed?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: That's at their peril
When they come to'th, field, but go they shall,
And they were my cousin-germans.

sp.speaker: Both Cit.
sp.l: Good my lord speak for us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You do not know my lords, but a little suffering
May save their souls and teach 'em, if they come
Off, with a quarter of their limbs, compassion
To other men, that venture their lives for 'em,
Their consciences are tough, and must be suppled,
When they shall fast, and march ten months in armour,
Sometimes through rivers, sometimes over mountains,
And not have straw at night, to keep their breech
From growing to the earth, in storms, in heats;
When they have felt the softness of a trench
Thigh deep in water, and their dung to fatten it;
When they shall see no meat within a month,
But chaw their match like liquorish, and digest
The bark of trees like salads in the summer;
When they shall live to think there's no such thing
In nature as a thirst, and wonder why
A tailor was created; when they have
As much in ready shot, within their flesh,
As would set up a plumber, or repair
A church with lead, beside ten thousand more
Afflictions, which they are sure to find,
They may have christianity, and not put
A soldier to the payment of his debts.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Tis a mad captain, come my lord let's leave him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You shall have time and place to send for money,
Or make your wills; set on, who knows but you
Hereafter may be honest, and prove captains;
You may have preferment in the wars for money,
And so my gentle creditors, march on.

div.head: Act. ii. enter Leandro with letters.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: The hope, and care of many years, are in
One day destroyed; hath heaven no stroke in war?
Or is old providence asleep? Leonario
Is coming home with victory, and brings
Young Ferdinand, whom I expected to
Salute a King, his prisoner, and the Queen
With her new conqueror, glorious in the spoils,
By putting out this light, will mix their beams
And burn our eyes out with their shine; there is
No talk but of this triumph, and the people
Whom I by art and secret murmurs had
Made doubtful at the first noise of this conquest,
As they had borrowed souls from fear, and folly,
Adore the rising star, and in the praise
Of him and his great fate, wonder that heaven
Should hold a sun, and he so bright; nor with
This flattery content, but they condemn,
(As low as all their sins shall one day them)
Him whom the chance of war hath made a prisoner.
There is no trust to policy or time,
The things of state are whirled by destiny,
To meet their period, art cannot repair 'em.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord, the Queen hath sent for you,
She is going forth to meet the prince, and hath
Commanded none be wanting to attend
With all the state that may become her, to
Congratulate the triumph now brought home.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: I shall obey. I must attend this glory;
It is not safe to wear a brow, but what
The Queen's example first forms into smile.
I here contract my knowledge, and seclude
My wishes, since they prosper not. I am
Her chancellor; as great offices, and high
Employments, do expose us to most danger,
They oft teach those possess 'em a state-wisdom,
And by inherent virtues of the place,
Our fear to lose, makes us secure ourselves,
By art more often, than by conscience;
But I may be endangered to suspicion;
I like not things; but I delay my attendance.

div.stage: Enter captain, lieutenant, ancient and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Ancient, what think you of the wars now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are come off with honour.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: And our limbs, captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Is that all? who made you a lieutenant?
And you ancient? these titles were not born w'e,
You did not wear these buffs and feathers in
The memory of man, when you received
The binding twelvepence, it was otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But you received, if you remember captain,
Beside what we released in honest debt
Sums for this great instalment, we ha' paid
I take it for our names.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And it became you,
Now you are gentlemen my comrades of honour,
And I dare walk and drink at taverns w'e,
Your oaths become you now, and your splay feet;
You looked before like maggots, city worms,
I ha' made you both brave fellows, fellows to knights.
You may be squires to ladies too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: We are all now of a trade,
For Mars is master of our company,
Our shop is the field, resolution our stock,
Honour our purchase, and fire and sword
The tools we work withal.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: But now the wars are done, I think
We may shut up our shop, there is no more
Pay, is there?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Pox upon you; I see your souls bleat after
Profit still, a bullet in the right place would
Have knocked out this humour of getting money;
But fear not, though you come off with more
Limbs than you deserve, you shall have pay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shall we and not be troubled to fight for't?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes, it will be necessary you fight, you will
Have your throats cut else, and be sent off like sheep,
Do not fear payment, here be mandrakes,
That will roar, and cudgel you to your hearts content,
You sha'not walk the streets now you are
Officers without a quarrel: pay enough.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: A man had as good be no lieutenant, as be
Beaten when he comes home what think you ancient?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For my part I can endure beating as well
As another if that be all.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Will you to your shops again?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have no mind to worsted stockings again,
And Shoes that shine, I would were colours still.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Well said ancient come I'll take your fears off;
Do not confess you are a lieutenant, or you an
Ancient, and no man will quarrel w'ee, you
Shall be as secure as chrisom children.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Shall we? they shall rack me ere I'll confess I am
A lieutenant or ever see the wars.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Or I an ancient. I'll take't upon my death
I was never a soldier in my life.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Tis well done; now because I love you,
And see you have an itch after honour, so
It may come without blows, let me advise you,
You have moneys at command.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: And good debts too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You shall both turn courtiers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shall we?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I say't; for if my phisnomy deceive me not,
You two are born to be —

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Coxcombs. I'll help to make you too;
You shall presently kiss the Queen's hand;
You have moneys you say, you shall never turn
To your vomit of small wares. I have friends
At court, you may in time be great; and when I come
With a petition to your honours, for moneys in arrear,
Or knocking out some rascals brains, such as you were
When you wore a girt under your chops, you two
May stand between me and the gallows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hang us if we do not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You shall buy places presently. But stay,
Have you a mind to be officers to the Queen
In ordinary, or extraordinary?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Extraordinary by all means.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: We scorn to be ordinary courtiers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I commend your judgement, that will be
Chargeable: but —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hang't, we'll find money enough, but I more
Resolve to be extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll bring you to a court-merchant presently;
You will get infinite estates.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: A ha captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And so command the ladies, if you be bountiful.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: A ha boy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: For I know you do love wenches;
You will have all the business, and the country
Come tumbling in upon you like the tide,
After a month: you must keep twenty men
Between you, night and day to tell your money.
O 'tis unknown what will become on you,
If you be ruled, and take this course: had I
Moneys like you, I would be —

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Come, we will lend thee moneys too hereafter.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Will you, come on, no more lieutenant now
Nor ancient.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye think we long to be beaten.

div.stage: Enter Ferdinand (In prison) Rosania (Like a page.)

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Pray do not grieve for me, I have a heart
That can for your sake suffer more; and when
The tyranny of your fate calls me to die,
I can as willingly resign my breath,
As go to sleep.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Can I hear this Rosania
Without a fresh wound? That thy love to me
Should be so ill rewarded, thou'st engaged
Thyself too much already; 'tis within
Thy will, yet to be safe, reveal thyself,
Throw of the cloud that doth eclipse that brightness,
And they will court thy person, and be proud
With all becoming-honor to receive thee,
No fear shall rob thy cheek of her chaste blood.
O leave me to my own stars, and expect
Whate'er become of wretched Ferdinand,
A happy fate.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Your council is unkind,
This language would become your charity
To a stranger, but my interest is more
In thee, than thus with words to be sent off;
Our vows have made us one, nor can the names
Of father, country, or what can be dear
In nature, bribe one thought to wish myself
In heaven without thy company; it were poor then
To leave thee here. Then by thy faith I charge thee,
By this — the first and last seal of our love. Kisses him.
By all our promises, when we did flatter
Ourselves, and in our fancy took the world
A pieces, and collected what did like
Us best, to make us a new paradise,
By that, the noblest ornament of thy soul,
Thy honour, I conjure thee, let me still
Be undiscovered; what will it avail
To leave me, whom thou lovest, and walk alone
Sad pilgrim to another world? We will
Converse in soul and shoot like stars, whose beams
Are twisted and make bright the sullen groves
Of lovers as we pass.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: These are but dreams
Of happiness, be wise Rosania,
Thy love is not a friend to make thee miserable,
Society in death, where we affect,
But multiplies our grief; live thou, o live.
And if thou hast a tear, when I am dead,
But drop it to my memory, it shall
More precious than embalming dwell upon me,
And keep my ashes pure, my spirit shall
At the same instant in some innocent shape
Descend upon that earth thou hast bedewed;
And kissing the bright tribute of thy eye,
Shall after wait like thy good angel on thee.
There will be none to speak of Ferdinand
Without disdain, if thou diest too: o live
A little to defend me, or at least
To say I was no traitor to thy love,
And lay the shame on death, and my false stars
That would not let me live to be a King.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: O Ferdinand,
Thou dost not love me now.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Not love Rosania?
If wooing thee to live, will not assure thee,
Command me then to die, and spare the cruelty
Of the fair Queen: not love Rosania?
If thou wilt but delight to see me bleed,
I will at such a narrow passage let
Out life, it shall be many hours in ebbing,
And my soul bathing in the crimson stream,
Take pleasure to be drowned. I have small time
To love, and be alive, but I will carry
So true a faith to woman hence, as shall
Make poor the world, when I am gone to tell
The story yonder. — we are interrupted.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: You must prepare yourself for present trial;
I have command to attend you to the judges.
That gentleman, and all that did adhere
To your conspiracy, are by the Queen's
Most gracious mercy pardoned.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: In that word
Thou'st brought me more than life; I shall betray,
And with my too much joy undo thee again.
Heaven does command thee live, I must obey
This summons, I shall see thee again Tiberio,
Before I die.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I'll wait upon you sir,
The Queen will not deny me that poor office;
I know not how to leave you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Death and I
Shall meet, and be made friends; but when we part,
The world shall find thy story in my heart.

div.stage: Enter officers with bar, table, stools, — then Ernesto, Rodriguez, Leandro, Queen, supported by Leonario, Ferdinand, Rosania, ladies, gentlemen, and guard, who set Ferdinand to the Bar.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Is that the prisoner at the bar?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He that pretended himself Ferdinand,
Your uncle's son.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Proceed to his arraignment; my lord Leandro,
You know our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Although the Queen in her own royal power,
And without violating sacred justice, where
Treason comes to invade her, and her crown
With open war, need not insist upon
The forms, and circumstance of law, but use
Her sword in present execution;
Yet such is the sweet temper of her blood,
And calmness of her nature, though provoked
Ino a storm, unto the greatest offender
She shuts up no defence, willing to give
A satisfaction to the world how much
She doth delight in mercy. Ferdinand,
For so thou dost pretend thyself, thou art
Indicted of high treason to her majesty,
In that thou hast usurped relation to
Her blood; and under name of being her kinsman,
Not only haste contrived to blast her honour
With neighbour princes, but hast gathered arms
To wound the precious bosom of her country,
And tear the crown, which heaven and just succession
Hath placed upon her royal head: what canst
Thou answer to this treason?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Boldly thus.
As I was never with the height of all
My expectation, and the aid of friends,
Transported one degree above myself,
So must not Ferdinand, though his stars have frowned
And the great eye of providence seem to slumber.
While your force thus compelled, and brought me hither
With mockery of my fate, to be arraigned
For being a prince, have any thought beneath
The title I was born to; yet I'll not call
This cruelty in you, nor in the Queen,
(If I may name her so, without injustice
To my own right) a kingdom is a garland,
Worth all contention; and where right seals not
The true possession, nature is forgotten,
And blood thought cheap to assure it; there is something
Within that excellent figure, that restrains
A passion here, that else would forth like lightning.
'Tis not your shape, which yet hath so much sweetness
Some pale religious hermit might suspect
You are the blessed saint he prayed too; no,
The magic's in our nature, and our blood;
For both our veins full of one precious purple
Strike harmony in their motion, I am Ferdinand,
And you the fair Olivia, brother's children.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What insolence is this?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O my lord, let him
Be free to plead; for if it be no dream,
His cause will want an orator: by my blood,
He does talk bravely.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: These are flourishes.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Speak to the treason you are charged with
And confess a guilt.

sp.speaker: Leond.
sp.l: He justifies himself.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: If it be treason to be born a prince,
To have my father's royal blood move here;
If it be treason, in my infancy
To have escaped by divine providence,
When my poor life should have been sacrificed
To please a cruel uncle, whose ambition
Surprised my crown, and after made Olivia
His daughter Queen; if it be treason, to
Have been a stranger thus long from my country,
Bred up with silence, of my name, and birth,
And not till now mature to own myself
Before a sunbeam; if it be treason
After so long a banishment to weep
A tear of joy upon my country's bosom,
And call her mine my just inheritance,
Unless you stain my blood with bastardy;
If it be treason, still to love this earth,
That knew so many of my race, her Kings,
Though late unkindly armed to kill her sovereign,
As if the effusion of my blood were left
To make her fertile, if to love Olivia,
My nearest pledge of blood, although her power
Hath chained her prince, and made her lord her prisoner,
Who sits with expectation to hear
That sentence that must make the golden wreath,
Secure upon her brow, by blasting mine.
If this be treason, I am guilty Ferdinand
Your king's become a traitor, and must die
A black, and most inglorious death.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: You offer
At some defence, but come not home; by what
Engine were you translated hence, or whether
Conveyed? There was some trust, deceived, when you
Were carried forth to be preserved, and much
Care taken since, in bringing of you up,
And giving secret fire to this ambition.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: There wants no testimony here, of what
Concerns the story of my birth and infancy,
If one dare speak, and be an honest lord.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Whose love and art secured me from all tyranny,
Though here my funeral was believed, while I
Sent to an honourable friend, his kinsman,
Grew safely to the knowledge of myself
At last, till fortune of the war betrayed me
To this captivity.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: I blush at thee
Young man, whose fate hath made thee desperate,
And carest not what man's blood thou drawest along
In thy black stream, or what man's faith thou mak'st
As hateful as thy crimes.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: That confederate
Sure has some name, declare him, that he may
Thank you for his reward, and lose his head for't.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We always see that men in such high nature
Deformed, and guilty, want not specious shapes
To gain their practice friendship, and compassion,
But he shall feel the punishment; d'ye smile?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A woman's anger is but worth it madam;
And if I may have freedom, I must say,
Not in contempt of what you seem, nor helped
By overcharge of passion, which but makes
A fruitless noise; I have a sense of what
I am to lose, a life, but I am so fortified
With valiant thoughts, and innocence, I shall,
When my last breath is giving up, to lose
Its self i'th' air, be so remote from fear,
That I will cast my face into one smile,
Which shall when I am dead, acquit all trembling,
And be a story to the world, how free
From paleness Ferdinand took leave of earth.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Alas my lord, you forget me, that can
Part with such courage.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I forget indeed,
I thought of death with honour, but my love
Hath found a way to chide me; oh my boy,
I can weep now.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A sudden change, he weeps.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What boy is that?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I prithee take thyself away.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Your spirit
Does melt it seems, and you begin to think
A life is worth preserving, though with infamy.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Goodness thy aid again, and tell this great
Proud woman, I have a spirit scorns her pity.
Come hither boy, and let me kiss thee; thus
At parting with a good, and pretty servant,
I can without my honour stained shed tears:
I took thee from thy friends, to make thee mine;
Is it not truth boy.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And meant when I was King to make thee great,
And shall I not, when I can live no longer,
To cherish thee at farewell, drop a tear?
That I could weep my soul upon thee, — but
You are to slow methinks . I am so far
From dread, I think your forms too tedious.
I expect my sentence.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Let it stay a while.
What secret flame is this? Honour protect me!
Your graces fair excuse, for you — I shall
Return again —

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And I, with better guard
After my silence in the grave, to meet
And plead this cause.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: He is distracted sure;
His person I could pity, but his insolence
Wants an example; what if we proceed
To sentence?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I suppose the Queen will clear
Your duties in't.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: But I'll acquaint her.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: My lord leandro's gone.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: His censure will
Be one with ours.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yet shall I publish who
Thou art? I shall not die with a calm soul
And leave thee in this cloud.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: By no means sir. — the Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Whose service is so forward to our state,
That when our pleasure's known, not to proceed,
They dare be officious in his sentence? Are
We Queen, or do we move by your protection?

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Madam, the prince —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: My lord, you have a Queen.
I not suspect his wisdom sir, but he
Hath no commission here to be a judge,
You were best circumscribe our regal power,
And by yourselves condemn, or pardon all,
And we sign to your will: the offence, which you
Call treason strikes at us, and we release it,
Let me but see one curl in any brow:
Attend the prisoner hither; — kiss our hand.
Are you so merciless to think this man
Fit for a scaffold. You shall sir be near us,
And if in this confusion of your fortunes
You can find gratitude, and love, despair not.
These men that now oppose, may find your title
Clear to the kingdom too: be sir collected,
And let us use your arm.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: What change is here?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: What think you of this lords?

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: I dare not think.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Affronted thus? O my vexed heart.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I'll follow still, and if this be no dream,
We have scaped a brook, to meet a greater stream.

div.head: Act. iii.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Though I believed her passionate, and like
A sea, tempestuous in her anger, I
Never thought she would marry him.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: She's the Queen,
But with what honour she could quit the prince,
Who (Without treason) did deserve her too,
Comes not within my reach.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: If you consider
He has been valiant for her to great purpose,
And brought a prisoner home, to mount his jennet:
It was a pretty service.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How does he bear it.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: He's here, you may inquire it.

div.stage: Enter Leonario (With letters) and a servant.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Be swift and faithful, Arragon bleeds here,
Nothing but war can right my cause and honour.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Expect an army great as your own thoughts
To cut the way to your revenge.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My lords Rodriguez and Ernesto.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Your grace's servants.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A man may take the benefit of this garden,
Without a court offence, you have had the day
Of triumph, and the Queen already teeming,
To bless the kingdom with an heir; and yet
You see I walk like a poor neighbour prince,
And have my heart still.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I am glad you bear it so.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nor have I a meaning
To run myself into despair, or strangle
My better hopes, out of pure melancholy,
I praise the influence of my stars; there is
A fire in Cupid's quiver, that will scorch
Through armour; and what's woman's flesh and blood
To make resistance, though I did not dance
Upon the marriage night, I wished her joys
I'th' morning.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Her heart showed she was pleased
With what she had done; she was as active as
The air before she went to bed.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: But I
Observed a declination in the King,
And as the night approached, which should have more
Enlarged his mirth, he grew more melancholy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Strange! And such a bride that took him from
So great a loss, to place him in her bosom;
But he was marked for the Queen's thoughts, and I
By destiny to bring this pair of pigeons
Together. I expect no more reward,
The willow garland crowns me, but the prince
Is here still.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Your highness hath a noble temper.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Howe'er he seem to cover it, his soul
Hath a deep apprehension of the affront.
Let's leave him, our discourse may be displeasing.
We are servants to your grace.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You've honoured me.
Think I am tame still? let the inconstant Queen
Secure her thoughts, and glory in my silence;
This heart is labouring a revenge.
Captain, what news? the court is merry still?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Not altogether so merry as it was hoped for.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Can there be an eclipse already?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I have not read the almanac for this year,
But by my court astronomy, I find
Our sun and moon are in no conjunction;
They take their fit by turns, the King was cold
And full of phlegm last night, and they that wait
Near both, report the Queen this morning looked
As she had wept.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O, tears of joy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Of anger rather, if you saw her sullenness.
She frowns on every man, she turned away
One of her servants but this morning, for
Presenting her with verses, that did praise
The King, and wish her fruitful. Her own page
Was whipped, for saying the King lay with the Queen
And might for ought he knew, get her with child ere morning.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou art humorous.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And so are they.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This begins well; and what
Do people talk abroad of me, and my
Affront?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why, they say they are sorry for you,
Especially the women.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou art pleasant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Some that are chief in counsel, privately
Suspect it but a trick of state; and that
You had discovered underhand the Queen
Was not —

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Leave this mirth; let me endear thy care
For my intelligence at court; I must
Not off so tamely; and expect me here,
After a small dispatch, I have more to impart.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your humble creature still sir. Alas poor gent '
Were I as capable to be entertained now, in revenge
I would mount all the madams in the court,
There should be nothing like a woman in't,
But I would touse and tumble: who are these?

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Pray sir take no offence, we have been enquiring
About the court for two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And cannot your four eyes see two gentlemen
I'th' court?

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Excuse us sir, we have seen many, you
May guess we have relation to the city sir,
And would be glad to meet two of our old acquaintances,
A brace of our tribe,
We hear, translated first out of the city,
To be sons o'th' sword, are since turned courtiers.
Pray d'ye know 'em?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes children of the gown, but their employment
Woe not give 'em leave to attend such vulgar conference,
And here comes one of the moon-calves, does he look
Like a haberdasher, that's one of the maids of honour
The weasel loves a hens-nest, and I have settled
This persuasion, that no woman can hold out,
Now he is sworn a servant extraordinary.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Sir do you know us?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: We were your neighbours, and of the same trade

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: They'll make him sweat; how the rogue gloats upon 'em

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: We were of your acquaintance, when you sold garters.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Go hang yourselves.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: And statute-lace.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Poor men that had some losses late by fire,
And would become my clients to procure
Some letters patents to beg by; alas, they are half distracted.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: He's proud — I have a parcel of periwigs
Please you, for old acquaintance, put 'em off for me,
Among some friends of yours at court, whose skulls
Are but thinly furnished; the hair is of a
Gentlewoman's spinning.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I could love this citizen, and owe him any money
For his confident abusing him.
He has bribed her absence with some ring or bracelet,
Lest she should taste the discovery now.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Methinks you need not be so proud.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I would have you to know that I am an extraordinary —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Proud coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Servant to the Queen. What I was,
I am willing to forget;
What you are, is apparent, I defy the
Dunghill I came from, and it is scandalum
Magnatum to be so saucy.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: I will not leave your worship so.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What will this rascal do with himself?
Here comes the other fool to make up the gemini.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hum, I will not know him — let me see —
The humble petition of —

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Save you matter —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee fellow do not trouble me —
Humbly praying — the Queen shall sign it.
Let me see this other —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Who the devil will bring him a petition,
This whelp has discovered him, and now would
Pretend himself most busily employed
About petitions to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hum, shall daily pray for — hum.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: More wit and money a your side; for your
Extraordinary place will not hold out.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Sir I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is it embroidered satin sir, or scarlet?
Yet if your business do hold weight and consequence,
May deserve to wear your thankfulness
In tissue or cloth of bodkin; ermines are for princes.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Alas my suit is not worth your wearing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good faith sir you must excuse me, at this time
My attendance is expected at the counsel, come
To my chamber by five o'clock in the morning
Four days hence, and you shall be sure to find
Me —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Asleep .

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: But do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hum. Yes I have seen your phisnomy, were you
Never in a conspicuous place, called the pillory.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: How, the pillory?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A skirmish, and it be thy will.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: If it were not in the court garden,
I would beat out thy brains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Take heed, for I am an extraordinary — sir

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Rat-catcher.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You may beat out his brains here as securely
As if you met him i'th' market; marry if you do
Not kill him outright, it is but the loss
Of your hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: I would it were but the loss of my left hand
To beat one of thy eyes out — are you an ancient?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thank you for that, so I might deserve
To be beaten. I am an extraordinary sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And deserves to be beaten accordingly.
You may kick him without danger.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: May I?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Look, your friend will show you a precedent
He is acquainted with the court latitude.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: This is no striking.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I know it is not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: They are subtle knaves, and know the law ▪

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: A pox upon 'em, I feel it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: At their peril say I, these poor things
Do not believe that we are extraordinary men,
I shall know you another time, I shall.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: If you had known him now it had been better
For your haunches. Well, I ha' not done with
These whelps yet, till they are undone.
I shall never be sufficiently revenged for their affront
At court. The prince commanded me to
Expect his return here, I'll not leave
The garden. Who's this?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Is perjury no sin? or can heaven be
So busy or asleep ? Such crimes of men
Pass with impunity? Let this wake your anger:
This; Ferdinand is married, all his vows
Scattered in th' air, dispersed like withered leaves,
And hurried on the wings of some rude wind,
Whose pride was to deflower the spring; o Ferdinand,
Couldst thou, whilst yet thy breath was warm with love,
With love of me, call back thy faith, and tear
Thy heart from mine to plant it in her bosom?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: What though she be a Queen? could any thirst
Of present title flatter thy soul from me?
I that left all for thee, and would have called
Death for thy cause a triumph, now must live
The scorn of my own thoughts, despised by thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Here's a new business; this obscures me quaintly.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: The King commands you not to leave the garden.
He espied you from the gallery window, and
Would have you here attend him.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Sir, may I
Without offence, ask if the King be merry?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: We are scarce yet acquainted with his nature,
But we observe no jubilee in his eyes,
Nor is the Queen so pleasant as our hopes
Did promise after marriage.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Pray excuse this boldness.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: You'll expect his pleasure here?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: 'Tis my ambition once more to see,
And speak with him, and if his language break not
My heart, I'll take my leave — the Queen.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: He is a servant to whom the King
Was pleased to show affection, when he had
No expectation of your royal favour.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I do remember, I observed him once
Use more than common passion to this servant,
And if we may build any confidence
Upon a fair aspect, he may deserve it.
Say we would speak with him; my heart's oppressed
With melancholy, something tells my spirit
I am too tame; have I advanced a thing
Without a name to perch on the same cloud
With me, and for his sake slighted a prince,
My honour, and his faith, transported with
My folly and his charms of tongue and person?
And dares he pay me with neglect and coldness?
O my vexed soul! but he shall find I have
A sense of my dishonour; and yet open
Ways become trivial and poor revengers,
I will do something that shall sting him to
Repentance; my lord you now may leave us.
Sir of what country are you?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Of Valentia.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Tiberio.
My parents not ignoble, yet too hasty
I'th' apprehension of prince Ferdinand;
His fortune (If I may yet call him so)
Gave me to be his page, I must confess
My diligence thrived so well since I came to him,
That he did value me above his servant.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Yet I've not seen you wait since we were married.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: It was no want of duty madam, I
Had late some wrestling with a fever, that
Compelled me to my chamber, and disabled me
For fit attendance.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Why dost weep?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I madam?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I see the tears.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: They are not sorrow then to see my master
Possessed of so much happiness in your love,
And I am confident, his soul so full
Of honour and regard to your great virtues
Will seal him worth your gracious favours madam,
And the world's envy.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I'll not blame him now
For loving thee; and so much hath thy faith
And innocence prevailed, thou shalt translate
Thy service, and be mine, he shall consent.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am to both most humble.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Prithee tell me,
Making so much of thee, he does impart
Sometimes the secrets of his bosom to thee.
Tell me what fault he has, for thou knowest all.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Alas madam I know none,
Or if I did, it ill became the trust
And duty of a servant to reveal 'em

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou were't his bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Gracious madam —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Does he not wanton in the night, and talk
Of mistresses.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: By truth not to me madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Dissemble not
Know he has a mistress.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: If love were ever so unkind to him —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Unkind? why is't a sin to love? I shall
Suspect thy youth has not been free, thy looks
Betray some seeds of love.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: By all that's good
Never was in love but with my master.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: He is not worth it.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Be wise, and govern well thy hopes. I'll help
Thee to a mistress; thou'st no mistress yet?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: But you self madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: It shall be no other.
Thy master is ingrateful.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Goodness aid him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And wisdom thee, thou art a pretty youth,
I will reward thee better, if thou canst
Be faithful and obey.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: In all things madam
That shall become your creature.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Tis not safe
To play with a Queen's favours, you shall wait
Near us; forget thy master, and be happy.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What clue can guide me in this labyrinth?
I would when I had lost Ferdinand's heart
I had lost my understanding. She returns.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The King is coming this way; now be free,
Thou shalt have reason afterwards to bless
Thy fate, this cannot choose but vex him.

div.stage: The Queen is pleasant with Ros.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The Queen so pleasant? she has lost her sullenness,
Plays with his hair, and smiles.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Madam, the King
Observes us.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Strokes his cheek too, she does want
A Ganymede; my poor Rosania
Art thou the path she walks on to revenge,
All is not well within her heart but mine
Sinks with the heavy pressure — she is gone.
The Queen does grace you much Tiberio,
Those favours are not common.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: She is pleased
For your sake sir to cast some smile upon me;
I know 'twas your request she should be kind,
To keep my heart alive .

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou'rt not discovered.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Did not you discourse
My story to her?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Take heed, yet this
Will add but a thin feather to the scale
Of my misfortune, she knows all, and in
The pity of my sufferings says you are
Not worth my love, and calls you most ingrateful

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We are both lost, till now there was some hope
How to repair thy sorrow.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Do not mock me;
'Tis a worse tyranny than to kill, to laugh
At what you have made wretched, 'tis as possible
To call past ages back.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Take heed Rosania,
And be not judge of what thou knowest not, dearest.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I know too much.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: That I am married.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: There's no truth in man.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are too rash; for there is truth in me,
In Ferdinand, though in thy thoughts held black
And stained prodigiously with breach of faith,
I have not broke my vow, do not compel me
By thy unbelief to do a sin I hate
As much as I love thee.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Have you a soul?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yes, and thy eye shall read it, be but calm,
That soul, thou once didst love, white with his first
Simplicity and faith; I won't urge
In my excuse the beauty of the Queen
Enough to melt a Scythian into love,
But call to mind my dear Rosania,
And do but put upon thee Ferdinand
So late forgotten by his stars, a prisoner,
Slaved like a villain at the bar, expecting
At every breath his sentence, nay admit
Rosania, the best part of his soul
Stood like a weeping fountain to take leave
Of what she never must salute again:
In this extreme, to preserve Ferdinand
And save Rosania, wouldst thou scorn the breath
Of mercy, that did court thee from the lips
Of a great Queen? couldst thou love Rosania,
If thou wert Ferdinand to lose thyself?
Whom she would follow in a stream of tears,
And when she had made an island of thy tomb,
Striving to swim to thee, she could not choose,
But drown herself in her own waves. I prithee
Take reason to thee, and when thou'st considered —

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Persuade me I am not Rosania,
And I will say 'tis virtue, and that yet
Your heart may grow with mine; is not the Queen
Possessed of that which should have been my title,
A wife to Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed the world
Doth think it so, I did consent to ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Call you enjoying of the Queen but ceremony?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Pause there, and if thou hast but so much charity
To think I dare not blaspheme heaven, I'll call
That, and the angels boldly to my witness,
The queen's to me a stranger yet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A miracle.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Retain but love, as thou preservest thy sweetness,
And that will teach thee to believe that Ferdinand,
Howe'er saluted King is still thy subject,
And though her husband, in my faith to thee
The marriage bed hath still our virgin sheets;
A brother might embrace a sister, with
The heat I brought; that this is truth, the power
And name I have, shall only serve to make
Our flight secure into another kingdom,
And when I part with these new shining glories,
Thy faith will be confirmed, and thou acknowledge
I ventured much to keep my heart thy servant.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I know not what to say; is not the Queen
Displeased?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: She is, but cunningly disguiseth
Her passion to the world; but I forgotten
What must enlarge my fears of her revenge
If thou be known Rosania.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Lose that fear,
I am still safe, and now I see the cause
Makes her repent her favours, and thy greatness;
Forgive me Ferdinand, and yet I know not,
All is not well, there's poison in this balsam
Prepared for thee.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Rosania.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: When she shall but consent to have me die,
She shall not trouble poison to send off
My despised life, my soul in just obedience
To her command will take a cheerful flight
In hope to serve her in the other world.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You shall know more hereafter, and let this
Secure your thoughts, she yet believes me what
This shape presents, but without wise prevention,
I fear I shall not live too long concealed;
I dare not say her honour is a bleeding,
But a Queen thus distasted may not find
That ice within her blood; we are interrupted.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: Your pardon sir; 'tis the Queen's pleasure
This gentleman attend her in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: He shall wait her commands —
I know not what to counsel, 'tis not safe
Sweet to neglect her, yet my fears of some
Ill fate, are round about me like a mist,
And dark my understanding; let a kiss
And silence teach our souls some new discourse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why here's a volume of intelligence
I'll stay no longer to expect the prince,
But seek him out immediately; disguises?
King by your leave, I shall untruss your mistress.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I know not what I feel nor what to fear,
If love e'er meant a tragedy; 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: If we ne'er meet again, one more salute
Shall fortify our lives by joining breath,
Nor shall our last hard fate deny us this,
To change our faithful souls at our last kiss.

div.head: Act. iv.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: I know not what to think on't, but if I
Have any sense, there is some new state madness
Crept into court.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: Are we not all asleep ,
And these fine dreams perplex us?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: No 'tis waking.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Show me the tenth part of a reason why
The Queen did marry him.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: 'Twas destiny.

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Why since should he be melancholy?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Or she so humorous?

sp.speaker: Ernest.
sp.l: Not lie together? pray heaven the gentleman
Be found with no defective title in him.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Observe her favours to that boy, he was
His servant, now her minion. I like not
These violent wheels; the whole frame may be soon
Endangered, if these passions be not cured.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: New lodgings for him, near her own, and he
Given free access to the bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: 'Tis naught
Or will be so, I pity the good King;
Though she have raised him to the highest glory
Her power extended too, yet to make this height
His precipice, and throw him into scorn,
Nay poison the best hopes he had of honour,
And love from her, and in his sight to court
A boy, his servant? It would vex the best
Of all our tempers, if we felt the sting on't.

div.stage: Enter Rosania and Violinda (Passing over the stage.)

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: He's here, that lady is the Queen's cabinet.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: They are merry about the mouth.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Another summons?
'Tis possible the Queen may marry him too.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: There is some mystery we cannot reach.
If we do well remember, there's a law
Made by herself, as soon as she was Queen,
To keep wife's pulses temperate, and correct
The insolent blood of women that had husbands.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And men were not exempted.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: I say no more.
But heaven maintain the law, and the lawmakers,
And conjure down that devil,
'Tis the King and the smooth boy, let's leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Was this the lady's message? does the Queen
Take thee into such favour?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I tell truth,
And though it sound but ill on the Queen's part,
Because she thinks me what I seem my lord,
You need not to wear one cloud upon your face
When you remember who I am, my fears
Are thick upon my heart, how to secure
This shadow any longer.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: That afflicts
Me most Rosania, for it pleases me
To hear she can affect thee; but what way
To keep her expectation high, and thee
(My dearest) safe? her passions may be violent.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: They are already sir, if I mistake not;
I wish to heaven that you were reconciled
To do the office of a husband to her,
That peace would keep her bosom clear, and I
Should live to all the world except yourself
A stranger still.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What language speaks Rosania?
There's death in every syllable; should I
Obey what thou desirest, and do the office
Of a husband, ha?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I'll wait upon you still,
And hope you will vouchsafe me now and then
A harmless smile; her beauty will deserve
Your whole heart, and there's something in the memory
Of what she has advanced you to, will help
To make you kind.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Should I enjoy the Queen?
Because the misery of my fate compelled
A ceremonious sin? shall I betray
The essence of my faith, and leave a curse,
When thou art known, upon my name for ever?
If thou hast taken new resolves against me,
Punish my heart some other way; had she
More ornament than ever met in woman,
Mistress of more perfection than poets
Invented for the Queen of love, to this
Were the proud empire of the world her own,
And she would make me lord of her, and these,
It would not buy me to the pleasure of
One night's embrace, my body shall not carry
My soul so far astray; the man condemned
To live in a perpetual snow, hath not
A purer frost within his blood.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: This but
Engenders a new grief although it bind
Rosania's heart there is yet one way left
And that ere I pronounce you must forgive;
There is a trembling in my tongue and I
Already feel such winter in my breath,
My timorous lips do wither.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Do not fright
My soul too much there's something threatens me
So like a loss of these, that I am left
A piece of shaking earth, death cannot look
To make me tremble so; canst thou forsake me?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Not in my heart but give my body leave
To seek some other place my lord to dwell in.
When I am gone into some wilderness,
You will find ease at heart, and love the Queen,
And perfect all; I'll pray you may live happy.
And hold intelligence with some gentle winds
That shall convey my wishes and return
What joys do follow you; the purling rivers
I'll teach your name and they which guide this way
Shall bring thee something Ferdinand of mine;
My tears I know will not be lost, which I
Will send thee daily by the courteous stream,
Clear pledges of my faith; consent my lord
I may depart and you shall choose your way,
To every blessing here.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Not till we meet
With one embrace, and take our flight together;
And I have thought a way to perfect it,
Observe my sweet Rosania, the Queen
Thou sayst affects thee, cherish it, with all
The softness of her creature; if she allow,
Kiss her, and promise what young lovers do,
Examine not, but by thy love to me
Be free in amorous language, if she have
Heat to a private meeting in her chamber,
Obey, this shall secure our love's ambition.
Inquire not, but resolve, and let me know
The time.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You will attempt no violence
Upon the Queen?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: By this —

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What if she have commanded me
This night?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To meet?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: In her bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Ha! obey it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: At a late hour.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: It shall beget our comfort
If thou consent.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: But shall I not expose
Myself to danger, if her love pursue
Immodest ends, since you advise I should
Apply myself to her desires?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: If she
Take too much flame, by some soft art delay her,
Till I come to close all; keep still thy person
Secret, the least discovery will destroy
Us both; the evening with much haste prepares
Thy visit and our happiness.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: I'll obey,
But be you sure to come.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Lose thou no time
Now to endear thee to her, let us part
Love will find balm to cure the wounded heart.

div.stage: A table, and lights, set out, then enter Queen, and Violinda.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Was he not cheerful when he promised thee?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: He was, and he was not.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I have a strange apprehension, and this doth feed it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I told him 'twas an honour worth his joyful
Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: If it should prove successful, my revenge
Were perfect, I'm resolute to pursue —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: It makes well
For your contrivement that the King and you do
Lodge at distance — stay, I hear a tread.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I hope 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Prince Leonario madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What comes he for?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Although I have small expectation
For my own sake, that you can pardon madam
This bold access, and at so dark an hour,
Yet when you have heard my business, you will know
Yourself so much concerned, I'll not despair
To find your mercy.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You prepare me for
Something of consequence.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Please you to dismiss
Your lady, I have something to deliver
Won't become her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Leave us — now,
Our conference is free, your grace's pleasure?
It must be matter of much essence, that
Could not expect till morning, but you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This time and darkness madam best becomes him,
Who for your sake blushes to see the day,
But I came not to chide my wrongs have learned
A modest silence, my approach is not
To name a suffering of mine but to
Discover what already is prepared
Against your peace and honour.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Is it treason?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It is, but threatens not your life, you may
Live many years upon the wound.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You fright me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Lose not the beauty of your cheek so soon,
Hide not beneath that cold and killing snow,
One rosy blush, and yet that pale would show
Like innocence which you have lost; o madam
Had you not made a forfeit of your truth
To me no storm could shake you but your soul
That made no change could know no fear; I come
To tell you what just providence hath done
In my revenge, your breach of vow is punished
With loss of faith in him to whom you gave
The heart you promised me, the King, whose pride
You built on my dishonour, is as false,
As you were.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This is passion but be
Not yet too rash in censuring him. Whom I
Have placed so near, I must defend, nor will
He need my strength, to make their blood account
That dare traduce his honour; he has a heart —

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A false one. I was born without a fear,
And dare upon his bosom (Wear he worth
The manly contestation,) write him perjured.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I would this were not envy; but admit
He be thus guilty, 'tis a fault in him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No madam, it is yours; that sin that poisoned
The expectation of my joys in you,
Hath made him false, and will excuse his story,
When you are named that broke your faith to me;
I can have no hope now to be repaired,
But if it be worth memory to know
The triumph waits on innocence, the world
Shall say the Queen deserved to meet a scorn
Deep as her wrongs to me.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Think so, and help to make the revenge greater,
Till the winds catch the black report and multiply
The shame, by scattering it about the kingdom,
Sit still, and careless of your fame, encourage
His private lust, his mistress now in court.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: A mistress in the court?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes madam, in the court.
And may one day think any second place
Too narrow to contain her greatness, she —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: As you're a prince no more; I have done ill,
And find the penance here it does agree
With his neglects, and adds new flame to my
Young jealousy; I feel a tempest rising;
By all your goodness leave me sir; I cannot
Now right you more than mourn, and give belief to you.
No more I pray you, by all your love to honour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I ha' done,
And take my leave, my everlasting leave,
'Tis time; how like the day, that flattered us
With cheerful light, are my desires fled hence,
And left me here a prodigy of darkness,
A walking hearse, hung round about with night,
Whose wings must one day cover all? farewell.
If any star look forth, it is to call
Me hence, and light me to another world.
Our lips are never like to meet again.
Farewell, if I but stay, I shall forgive her.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: A mistress in the court? something is busy
About my heart.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The prince is gone.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: No matter.
Affronted thus? but I forgotten to ask
Her name that rivals me; how this passion
Befools our understanding, and prevents
The knowledge, and the cure of what afflicts us!
The morning will assure all; but shall this
Strike me to ashes? I may find a way
To my revenge.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Tiberio is come madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Wait carefully.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I know my duty.

div.stage: Enter Rosania: (Kneels and kisses her hand.)

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Rise,
This meeting was not meant for ceremony,
There's something in this presence will deserve
We should put off all state, and speak like friends.
You must be covered too. I'll have it so.
We are private now.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: These graces will
Undo a youth, whose birth, and careless stars
Ordained him to be humble, and with duty
Wait on your meanest servant.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou shalt soon have cause
To think thy stars are careful of thee, if
Thou canst be wise.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Alas! my years are few.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thy knowledge is not wanting to distinguish
Whose favours court thee, and apply thyself
To understand, and thank the kind bestower;
'Tis in my power to make thee great.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: You may
Advance this worthless walking shadow madam,
And when you like the free and bounteous sun
Have blessed me with your rays, it is but like
His glorious warmth bestowed upon a piece
Of rude and barren earth, which takes not from
The lustre of your beams, but shows more clearly,
By your own light, what poverty you shined on.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This modesty becomes you not, look in
My eye, and read what's there.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Some thing like anger,
Enough to strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: A smile,
And such attending sweetness —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thus it shall
Invite thee still to gaze, and love, Tiberio,
No frown shall point on thee; I find my eyes
Were meant for thee, and all they graced before,
But objects of mistake. Here, here, oh turn
Thy lovely face away, left I be seen
To blush, my heart hath chose to place my love
And the reward; this would become thy tongue
A great deal better, come sit down Tiberio.
What still an infant's understanding? Think
I am the man, and learn a little better,
What beauty dwells upon this hand, what softness,
How like the snow, or innocence it shows,
Yet fires my heart with every gentle touch.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Dear madam; would the King would come.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This is a happiness that Kings should sue for,
And yet there are poor comforts in these kisses;
Let hands preserve society with hands,
And with there change of whiteness, and of balm,
Make wealthy one another: but let what
Was meant for kisses meet, and find out pleasure
By warm exchange of souls from our soft lips. Kisses.
Madam, how like you this?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I suppose you a lady all this while,
