And I the man, our lips must meet again,
Will this instruct thee nothing?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Gracious madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And yet this recreation comes short,
Dear lady, of what love might well allow us.
Admit you are a Queen, you are not bound
To thin your royal blood with frost, but as
Your power, your pleasure should exceed; nay grant
You have a man (A man said I) that can
Keep love alive, and warm a yielding bosom,
Yet where from the invitement of your eye,
And amorous choice, I am become your servant,
You may be a little kinder.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Madam, I know not
How with the safety of myself, my duty,
And your own name and power, to understand you,
(Yet this to some would need but little comment)
Can you place such a value on a thing
That not deserves to breathe your name? Or should
I hope these charms of language you have spread
To catch my heart which hath no wings, but where
It can believe; for you transcend so much
In wonder of your love, a willing faith
Not easily can reach it. But dear madam,
I know all this is but to try my duty,
And you have pleased to choose me forth, to make
These silent hours more grateful, by the mirth
My weak replies may raise you,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Miracle!
I but imagined thee a woman, now
I shall believe thee one indeed; this coldness
Becomes no masculine habit. Come, we'll in,
And change our sexes; thou shalt wear my clothes,
And I will put on these, help on with thine,
And I will dress thee handsomely, and then
We'll act again.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Not for the world dear madam, not yet come?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The world? This confirms my jealousy.
I'll search you to the soul, Adonis come,
I'll call thee so, and court thee with more charm
Than Venus did, when in the Idalian groves
To buy a kiss, she offered the proud boy
Her flaming chariot, and her doves of snow.
'Tis in thy power to make thy fate and heart
More happy by consent to meet with mine;
Tempt not the anger of a Queen despised,
Whose breath can like a whirlwind snatch thee up,
And drop thee in a wilderness, where with sorrow
For thy neglect, thou by degrees mayst sigh
Thyself into a mist, which no sunbeam
Shall pity or take up into a cloud.
But love me, and compose thy heart to mine,
We'll live with more delight, than fancy can
Enrich Elysium with. The soft hours shall stay
Till we allow 'em wings, and while we kiss
And on each others lips breath incense thus,
We'll have ten thousand Cupids for our guard,
Whose bows shall awe the destinies, and we write
The King and Queen of fate.

div.stage: Enter Ferdinand, Leandro, Rodriguez, Ernesto, captain, guard.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Will this deserve your faith?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: We must believe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: We are undone, the King.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: False keys?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: 'Twas time to come.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Had I not cause, my lords, to appear sad,
When I suspected this so great affront?
My melancholy all this while was but
A mourning for this shame: look but my lords
Into yourselves, and make this suffering yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Madam be raised again, I have an art
To fetch you off with honour, and the youth too.
I will persuade him there can be no cure
In this extreme. but to pretend himself
A woman; I will dress him in your gown
Before they can be ware on't; they all know
This way he cannot fly, mean time put on
A confidence, and let them know you are
The Queen, not to be shaken with their power;
This will gain time.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Prosper in this.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will
Redeem my fault, or never sleep again.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: She blushes not.
Were she nor Queen, what names could we bestow
Upon this want of modesty?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: 'Tis plain.
We came in time.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Most happily to prevent
Some further act of shame; can she look on us
Without a blush?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I see no such attraction
In your state faces, that I should desire
Much to look on 'em. Who made you King I pray?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Your power I dare not call it love, presuming
That I was fit to be your property,
Without a soul to see, or have a sense
Of these dishonours; this rank heat of blood,
Madam, what penitence can make this clear?
Admit your thoughts were wanton, and your flame,
Too great to be suppressed, could you find none
For your adulterate embrace, but one
That was my servant? my own hound devour me?
As if your lust had not enough of shame
And mischief to me, but your malice must
Appear in't too; with what security
Can I expect to live, when she begins
So soon to poison me?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: We heard her say
They two would write themselves the King and Queen,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So we did all.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You may consider these.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: 'Tis impious
Madam with what grief do we
Remember now that law you made
After your coronation to preserve
The name of your sex chaste which gave our hearts
Hope of your blessed progress; you made it death
To stain the marriage-bed; where shall we expect
The life of that good act, when you begin
A breach of chastity by so black example?
If the King urge an execution
Of what our vote confirmed by yours imposed
Upon the kingdom, you should prove yourself
More innocent or give us cause to mourn
This fall from virtue

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Madam we grieve for you.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: So, so, have your great wisdoms said all yet?
I laugh at you (Poor things) and am so far
From trembling at your thunder, that I pity you;
And first I'll let you know you selves, you are
I take it all my subjects, I will not
Exempt you sir, since marriage takes not off
My interest, and essence here all strength
Flowing from me, and your derivative shine
Extinct, when I frown you to darkness; by
What power dare you take an account of me?
That am above your laws, which must obey
Me, as their soul, and die when I forsake 'em?
But I will reason coolly, and admit
They live in force;'gainst whom? are you so shallow,
To think we that created, and decreed 'em
For vulgar reformation, must be squared
And levelled by 'em, as we meant to lose
Our character and distinction, and stoop
Toth' common file of subjects? this were policy!
I speak not this with sense of any guilt,
So to decline it, for I here defy you,
And bring an innocence shall strike a blush
Upon your souls; that sinned in my suspicion.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Where is the boy? Ernesto take him to
Your custody, and bid him not despair,
I have contrived the rest.

div.stage: Enter Rosania (Like a woman) and Violinda.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Take it upon you, if it come to searching
We'll find a jury.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You are deceived my lord, with your good pardon, he is not here.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Who is not here?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The he you do expect;
And your officious ladyship might well
Have spared your pains, to put on all this trim.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What means the fellow?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Tis no news to your sir.
I could have told the Queen before and you
My honourable lords, this was no boy,
Though now he would but seem o'th' tother sex,
I knew her name.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My name?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Are not you called Rosania?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Ha! betrayed?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes indeed is she, you were present sir
I'th' garden when this fine hermaphrodite
Declared what sex was hid behind the breeches,
And this I certified the prince before.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Now 'tis clear.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: There are some tokens too I can remember,
As kisses, and excuse for marrying with
The Queen, a virgin still, etc.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A woman?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But are you a woman indeed?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And now my lords, if you have hearts that are
Honest and daring come about again,
For this is but a cunning piece of treason,
Against your faith, and the Queen's honour.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We are both lost Rosania.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Tis truth, or take my head off.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You do believe this transformation,
And know this lady, my good lord, I did
Suspect before the cause of your neglects,
And meeting with some dark intelligence
From the prince, to perfect this discovery,
Did in my chamber woo with aptest forms
Of love, to try how long the sex would be
Concealed; you heard a part, and see us kiss,
And came in time with these wise noblemen
To prevent further acts of shame.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: It was an ill contrivement to make me
Proof of the Queen's dishonour.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: An apparent plot
Against the life and honour of the Queen,
Since he would urge that law maliciously
Against her, knowing this to be a woman,
And his close strumpet.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: The same law must be
Their trial.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: What a change is here already?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You must not lords deny me justice.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: 'Tis insufferable
Against a common person.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Let his first
Treason, if you think good madam, be urged
In accusation.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You did us service captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I am bound to't, here's more news for the prince.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Use your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What need we circumstance, let him die tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Death will be mercy to so much ingratitude,
Command them both to several custodies.
The morning shall behold 'em dead —

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Now more lost than ever.

div.stage: Exeunt. Manent. Fred Ros. and guard.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Pray let's take
Short leave of one another, 'tis in vain
To reason against providence, or say
We might ha' lived; though I must die, and after
Be hid in my obscurest name, and shade,
I must declare whose blood they will profane
In bleeding thee; farewell, our last, last kiss.
My heart would fain come to thee, I will make it
My humble suit with my last breath it may
Be quickly sent thee.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: We shall both meet, when
This dust falls off, and our souls kiss again.

div.head: Act. v.
div.stage: Enter Leandro, Rodriguez, Ernesto, servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: My lord you tell us wonders, 'tis high time
To open such a mystery.

sp.speaker: Rodri.
sp.l: This change
Will exceed all, and so convincing are
The circumstances of this great discovery
They do command our faith.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And you shall steer us.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Then let us lose no time; o my good lords,
Did you but feel the torment of my bosom,
Till I discharge the duty, which so long
Hath slept in his concealment, you would call
For wings to fly, and think all motion tedious;
For heaven's sake let's make hast, that we prevent
The morning, which will rise upon this knowledge
With cheerful beams, and put on all his glory.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Most gladly we attend.

div.stage: A table and taper set out. Enter Ferdinand (With a book in his hand.)

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I have no heart to think of any thing
But my Rosania, all devotion,
When I remember her, flies off, and leaves
My soul no contemplation but her safety;
They were too cruel to divide us, night
Itself looks now more black by this dim taper;
Rosania's eyes would brighten all, but they
Weighed down with sleep, and sorrow, are perhaps
At rest, a thousand angels watch about 'em;
And let some one whose office is to wait
On harmless love, present me to her dreams;
Oh let her hear me often call upon her,
As I am led to death, and when the stroke
Divides me from myself, and from the world,
My heart shall pay her tribute, and my blood
Do miracles, when every crimson drop
My body bleeds, shall not in vain be wept,
But fall into some letter of her name,
To keep alive our story.
sp.stage: Enter two servants (With torches) Leandro, Ernesto, Rodriguez.
sp.l: What lights are these?
This place sure is not wont to be thus visited.
They are spirits, ha! yet if I have a memory
Those faces were but late familiar to me.
What mockery is this? if you be substances
Of things I know, go tell the tyrant Queen
She might allow me death without this scorn,
This jeering antimasque.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live the King.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What King?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live Ferdinand King of Murcia.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A dream, a golden dream. What fancies wait
Upon our sleep? and yet I wake, they are
Apparitions, I'll shut my eyes, and lose 'em.
They won't vanish Leandro, Rodriguez, Ernesto?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: All your subjects.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Collect your scattered thoughts my lord, and be
Assured, we now pay real duties to you,
You are our King, and must be.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Who says so?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Ay, whose cold fear, and frailty,
When fate of what had made you prisoner,
Concealed the truth, and justice of your title,
'Twas I that saved you from your uncle's fury
And sent you to Valentia, while I cozened
The kingdom with your death, till time might ripen
Your challenge to the sceptre; if you can
Find mercy to a treason, great as this,
I'll live, and study how to merit pardon.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Rise, rise all,
And if you be Leandro, pray come nearer.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pray heaven this unexpected happiness
Meet with no ecstasy, all senses are
Not armed for such extremes of joy.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: The Queen,
When she finds this, will fall into a fever,
By instinct her head must ache this very minute.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And shake too, for the crown is tottering.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Pardon? thou shouldst divide the kingdom with me.
But do all these believe it, will you not,
When I make second claim, deny me again?
Call me impostor?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Sir forgive that first,
And I'll not ask heaven pardon for my next
Denial, let death threaten all his stings;
And I have satisfied these lords so well,
They are confirmed in your just claim, and person.

sp.speaker: Rod Er.
sp.l: We lay our lives and fortunes at your feet.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I may command you then, fetch me Rosania;
I'll be no King without her; do not stay
To hear how much I love her above the crown,
And all the glories wait upon it, she
That was my page, my fellow prisoner, Rosania.
'Tis that name next to heaven I bow too.
Good my lord follow him, and if she be
Awake, o drop it gently by degrees,
(The joy is mighty, she a sad weak virgin)
That I shall live to make her Queen.
Stay you, and if I play too much the wanton with
My fate, or swell with expectation,
Speak something to allay my hopes, and say
There may be crosses yet, the Queen may want
Faith or consent, or put case the people
(A dangerous torrent to oppose) like not
This innovation, where is the King then?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Doubt not their loves, you had their
Hearts before;
Let nothing shake you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou'rt my better angel.
Why then if my Rosania will be Queen,
The kingdoms ours again; she comes, she comes.
Thou mak'st too little haste to be a Queen.
I am myself again, my name is found,
I shall live to, thus to embrace Rosania
Without a fear, these lords are all thy subjects,
I am a King.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: You are.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Then what must my
Rosania be?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Happy, if this be more
Than dream, my tears and sufferings are all paid for
If this be true.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What a strong arm
Hath heaven?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: See how the day hath made
Hast to salute Rosania, and to wait
Upon thy triumph, blushes like a maid
When she is told she is in love, the stars
Are gone to tell the other world, thy beauty,
Till now eclipsed with sorrow, hath thrown off
The imprisoning veil, and shines above their brightness.
But how shall we Leandro now contrive
For our court entertainment, where the queen's
Prepared to hear our tragedy?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Leave me
To order your appearance; but first sir,
We must secure this fort.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: The captain is
My creature.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou shalt be all our direction.
Come my Rosania, time hath turned again
Our glass, and his keen sith this comfort brings,
It cuts no sceptres down but to make Kings.

div.stage: Enter Leonario (Reading a letter,) and soldier.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: So near?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: We heard before of your affront
My lord, and were prepared.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It hath outstripped my expectation,
These letters say
Mendoza is their general new returned
With victory from the Moors; his fame I honour,
My knowledge never reached his person.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Sir, he brings old soldiers with him, the commanders
Are such, whose faith and valour in those wars
Already tried, he durst name to the King
To be employed here in your highness' cause.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: We will to horse immediately. I long
To salute the army.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Which but wants your person
The soul of their design; you may soon reach 'em.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your grace.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That we had wings, away, to horse to horse

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Speed, and you be so hot o'th' spur, my business
Is but breath, and your design it seems rides post.
The earth runs upon wheels; whom do I spy?
My extraordinaries, I'll ha' sport with them,
But first observe 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I see no profit in these offices
That we ha' brought.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not extraordinary, as the name did promise

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The rogues are poor, and now repent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We were told by the cheating captain
That we should want men to tell our money.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: This 'tis to deal with soldades.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We should command the ladies too, and we
Were bountiful, a small pox take their beauties,
'Tis the greater curse, I have undone
Myself in giving away enamelled rings
And bracelets.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Well, if I trust a captain again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Or I.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'm glad they are paid; I won't leave 'em
I feel my antipathy strong yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would venture half my soul to be revenged
If I knew how.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: True rascals!

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: The ladies love him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They all love men of war.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Would his poop were a fire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And battles in bed naturally.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Well, what ladies give him hereafter to buy new feathers, may his body compel him to bestow upon a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: May diseases undermine his flesh like gun powder,
And blow all his skin up into blisters.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: May they that look for his nose, go about for want of a bridge, and let him wear no legs but what he buys from the carpenter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: May his face break out, and undo him in taffeta, and may the patches at the last be so many, till his skin be invisible, and his goggle eyes look through a mask.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: May he live to be as much coward as we ha' been, and be beaten!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Abominably beaten, and may the miracle be on our side, that we may be valiant, and be the men to do it, o I would have no more mercy. —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Save you gallants, save you courtiers.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: My noble captain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It may be he did not hear us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hark you, what purchase have you two made lately?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Of lands and loggerheads, lordships I would say,
I know you are both rich, you cannot choose,
But I will borrow no more of you, faith be satisfied
And leave off in time with the wealth you have.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Where is it captain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Can you tell where we may borrow as much money upon our extraordinary places, as will set up shop again? For this court trade wo' not do.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: No indeed captain we ha' made little benefit since we came to be extraordinaries.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ye took not the right way then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That may be.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, cannot you lie, and swear, and pawn your souls for six pence, the devil could not furnish the city with two more hopeful borachios. You have a carrot-coloured beard, and that never fails, and your worship's face is a prognostication of preferment
sp.l: Is a prognostication of preferment, where
Beside dominical letters you have all the
Conjuring characters of the planets.
But all this is your cunning, to dissemble your estates.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: By this empty pocket, I have but one shirt

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You jest i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And by all my no money, I have but half a one left

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, come, you took up linen lately, I heard you did.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ay, smocks.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why they are in fashion with extraordinary courtiers.
sp.l: But if you be in earnest, I can tell, where you
May furnish yourselves richly.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why in the shops for ready money, but you would save charges.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I marry captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Venture to rob a hedge, it is but hanging,
And what's that to men extraordinary?
But if your wants be real, be not dejected,
I'll set you up again myself, I have been
Beholding to you two for your good words
And wishes gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: It pleases you to say so, I begin
To smell. —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not to us captain, we have been beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And it happens, as if fortune had made you miserable
A purpose to bless you both with such a preferment, as won't be offered again in a coronation.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: On good captain, for we are extraordinary miserable.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Then observe; you are not ignorant how things go at court, the King is in prison.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And his wench with him that walked in breeches; the Queen resolves they shall both die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: This morning too; now in regard the King is a person of quality —

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I think he be.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And the tother a lady, as some imagine, you two may do very well to undertake now —

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: To be a couple of hangmen: d'ye mark? to dispatch the Queen's enemies in what horrid way, her counsel shall think convenient, you will do service to the state, and have extraordinary rewards; besides the honour and reputation of your places; what say? 'tis my pure love to make this first offer to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do we look like a couple of hangmen?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No you ha' not so good a complexion; and now I think on't you sha'not live to have that preferment come, draw you that wear your sword like a bum-baily, do as I bid you, and that quickly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It won't come out sir —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No. — this shall in then —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will put more strength to't.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So, now, d'ye mark — kill one another.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Kill one another?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes and do't religiously, with as much alacrity as you would devour an orphan: and do't handsomely, that you may not be hanged when you are dead.
sp.l: I'll see't done, he that is dull shall have my goad to quicken
Him: —
So, good, good again, well offered — they fight by these hilts
Furiously, now could I forgive 'em — so, enough.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: This is very fine sport.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Necessity has taught 'em the noble science, come. if all fail, you shall fight challenges; there's money and
broken pates to be got that way, you can make legs, and gape like gudgeons for benevolence, cut scurvy capers, to show your legs are well, when your head bleeds; farewell; stay, you want money, I had forgotten, there is twelve pence apiece for you.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: How captain? I hope not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: They are not hearty yet, they think I serve 'em with press money again; no, 'tis my pure bounty. Go, set up again, and trust soldiers, without impertinent asking for your debts; they I pay you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As you ha' done.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll hearken how you behave you selves farewell. When you are rich, I'll visit you again, and borrow money.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Too much is too much; humh.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now have I a great mind to fight with your captainship.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: So have I, now my hands in, methinks 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You are not desperate?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We are a little better, as good be hanged for killing of you captain, as live after the rate of our disgrace. I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Two mastiffs at once may worry me. I am put to't.
Must we have tother 'Bout.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This is enough at once we may come to't in time.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why now I love you, love you, as well as you do la.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Upon good terms we love you too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let's shake hands, you sha'not to your vomit again. Now you dare sight, I'll tell you a hundred ways to get moneys, come, we'll drink and divide fortunes, run not back into cows again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll be ancient now again.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: And I lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Both my own boys.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis not so hard to fight I see, if a man be but desperate, and give his mind to't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Pox a coward's; come captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let me hug ye my brace of Myrmidons, and drink a tun of wine to this conversion.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The prince so early met upon the way
This morning sayst? and with a soldier?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And in that hast too, madam, I was told
The speed of wings was slow, their fiery horse
Bathing in foam, yet fled as if they meant
To leave the wind, and clouds behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Strange!
I could have wished him with less discontent
To have left us, but my stubborn fate designed it;
Having thus snatched away himself, it will
Become us to compose, and make the best
Of our state game; I sent a messenger
With our command, to th' governor of the fort,
He should attend the King by the water-gate
Leads to the garden, we do purpose conference;
If Ferdinand wisely consent to break
The magic that so chains his heart to that
Idol Rosania, we'll be reconciled,
And peace shall marry once again our hearts.
Methinks our lords are cold in their attendance,
Where be our train of ladies? — nay permit 'em,
A solitude becomes this sullen day.
And our own thoughts; methinks thou dost not look
With thy own face upon me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Not I madam?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: My eyes have lost their virtue, all I look on
Have not the shape and colour they presented.
What whispers that? ha'?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Here was none madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I could be jealous of the wind methinks,
And quarrel with the postures of those very
Shapes i'th' arras; fie Olivia, call home thy reason.

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.l: O madam!

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What horror's in that voice? I see a treason
In's looks.

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.l: O madam, I beseech your pardon.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Why? art a traitor?

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.l: Not I, but there are practises I fear
Against your royal person; the court gates
Are shut, all's in confusion within,
And I could hear abroad loud acclamations
And triumph for the King, as he were new proclaimed.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Which way comest thou?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Over the wall madam; the gates are shut,
I'll tell you news; young Ferdinand your husband
Is in all state attended, and proclaimed
King in his own right, he is proved to be
What he did first pretend himself, Leandro,
And all the lords confirm't, the governor
Hath given him up the fort, the wise city
Her keys, and every officer on's knees
Is praying and drinking the King's health,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Away and let thy face be seen no more,
But when the fatal noise of fire, some blood,
Or burial calls thee forth.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: This my reward
For bringing news the king's alive? take heed,
Do not talk treason in your own defence, — hark

div.stage: Enter (In state) Rodriguez, Ernesto, Leandro, Ferdinand, (Who takes the throne) attendants.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: From what an expectation am I fallen!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live Ferdinand King.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We thank you; and will study to be worth
Your prayers and duty; madam the chancellor
Can clear, and bring your faith to allow the wonder,
We are no impostor now, nor need we borrow
A beam from you to make us shine yet still
You are our cousin, fair Olivia,
The husband was a title long since due
To my Rosania, may it prosper here.
Our love and years grew up together, and
Our souls by holy contract tied, when in
Alfonzo's house, her father, and my guardian
(To whose trust I was sent an infant by Leandro)
We plighted faith; it is no blemish
To fair Olivia still to be a virgin,
Though she have lost the Queen, she is a Princess.
And hath now found a kinsman, that shall study
What shall become his love, her blood, and honour.
Upon your lip I print this fair assurance.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: And mine shall be to do you service madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: If this be true, you must command my duty.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We hear prince Leonario is departed,
When he shall know the progress of our fortunes
He'll quit his stars, that hid their golden heads
To mock him with a small eclipse, of purpose
To light him with more glory to his happiness. Soft alarum
Ha? what clamours that? the frightful noise increases.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Fly, and save yourselves the fort's surprised by the prince of Arragon, whose troops have seized the city, reeling with wine, and careless of their strength, in their joys for you sir.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: The prince of Arragon? the fates cannot
Be so injust, so envious of our blessing,
To snatch it from us in a minute; ha?
Help, help, quarter.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: They are i'th' court already.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: We are all undone,
Let's yield, and ask conditions honourable.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Die he, that dares but think so yield? no, Ferdinand
Was here too late a prisoner; let us sell
Our lives at glorious rates, the evening puts
A mask upon the horror, follow me.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: To certain death; ladies stay you, the danger
Will meet us here to soon, and yet your persons
In honour challenge safety.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Is there no end of my distractions?
Or hath my folly yet deserved more vengeance?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: It cannot be heaven will so soon destroy
The blessing it bestowed if thus you punish
Whom you advance, who will believe your gifts
Are more than flattery to betray our peace?

div.stage: Enter Leonario Alfonso, Ferdinand, (Prisoner,) Rodriguez, Ernesto, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This lady is my prize.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: How sir, your prize?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Mistake me not, there's no dishonour meant
Your person; yet I boldly may pronounce
You are, and must be mine. I am not ignorant
You are a virgin all but name, be wise
As you are fair, and I forget what's past,
And take this satisfaction; if I meet
Contempt, where I with honour once more court you,
You will create a flame shall never die
But in the kingdom's ashes; you were mine
First by your own election, sealed above,
If I must lose what heaven bestowed upon me
The quarrel is not mine
But virtues, whose right hand is armed with justice.
Punish not where you owe your heart, but let
Both our revenges meet in that impostor;
I find your noble soul return; lord general
While I retire with this fair Queen whom not
One violent accent shall affright, much less
A rude attempt, take hence that counterfeit,
And cut his head off.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O my dearest lord?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The rest may if they please find mercy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I were best be of this side.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Insulting prince, thou darest not.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How sir, dare not?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I said it,
Thy better, being a King in my own right,
Without her charity, proclaimed and justified,
By birth a prince.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: All this is truth sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You must not cozen thus my faith, away;
Cut off his head.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Dispatch you with the Queen,
Let me alone to make his head secure.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Nay take mine too. I'll wait on him in death,
It shall begin my service.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Cruel prince.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What fate must I obey?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My death will add some lines
Unto thy bloody chronicle; pray let us die together.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You shall speak, her sentence madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: She must live then.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To all we offer mercy, but to Ferdinand,
His doom is fixed; come madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Whither sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know the way to your chapel, he that loves us
Make haste, and bring the priest.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: That's I, I know
Her chaplains, they are my friends, and all good fellows.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Pray can you tell me, where, or what I am
Or what I must do next?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Yes, you must die.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Let not that grieve you gentlemen, 'tis nothing
To part with life, and if but my Rosania would not weep
Methinks I could shake off this dust, and leap
To immortality without a guide,
And in that cheerful flight prepare the blessed
With so much praise and wonder of thy virtue,
They shall be more in love with thee, than I,
And double all their prayers to bring thee to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: No, we will die together.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Both live, and love, and bless my age the witness.
D'ye know me?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Father?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Guardian.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Alfonso, my noble kinsman.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: How joys flow in my heart, to see this constancy!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: How came you to be his?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: I have deceived the prince our forces are Valentia's,
Not Arragon's, which he by letters sent for
In his revenge, but we met the intelligence
And arrived sooner to pretend ourselves
The army he expected; you shall know more hereafter.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I want a knowledge where to begin my gratitude,
The joys you bring are mighty, and overcome us.
O my Rosania?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: This was beyond hope.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So, so, 'tis done, he has mumbled up the ceremony;
A compendious priest may do much in few words;
They are fast enough; the Queen was wise to take him;
You are only like to be a loser sir; they come.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: All joys to the prince of Arragon, and the fair Olivia.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why not the Queen Olivia?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Not while this gentleman's head is on, believe it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Where is Mendoza?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Hid within this bush —
But here's Alfonso general of the army
Sent from Valentia to assist King Ferdinand
To his native right.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Valentia?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: My master having failed in his first aids
To Ferdinand, intended not sit down
With so much loss, but raised another army,
Which in our march consulted our security
By interception of all passages;
Your messenger by a party was surprised,
Him, stubborn to discover what he was,
Imperfect in his answer, we interpreted
Some spy, and searching found your letters fraught
With mischief and revenge, these sent to our King
We had command to hasten our design,
And steer our course by sea to Carthagena,
How after we arrived, we gained your faith
And purposes, your highness knows.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Betrayed?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Sir, be a prince, and just to your own honour,
And having perfected your fair desires
With her, we hope you will account yourself
Most happy that you missed a power to serve
Further revenge upon a lawful prince,
My soldiers will obey me now, although
To help your marriage I appeared no friend
To Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: Who was the prince preserved
By me, and sent an infant to this lord,
My noble kinsman.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Him I bred, till time
And strength might arm him to return, and claim
His own.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Leandro denied this before.

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.l: To my dishonour, 'twas a coward fear
To lose myself unprofitably

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I apprehend with wonder.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: If you repent not love and our alliance,
She shall be worth your best embrace, and we
Forgetful of your passion, entertain you
With all affection to our blood.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I meet it,
And satisfied in this story, joy I was
Prevented; I congratulate your stars sir;
Nor is this treasure of less price to me
Than when her temples were enchased with empire.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This love will give my soul another form.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Our story hath been full of change, but love
Hath met a glorious victory, and tied
Our souls together with most firm embraces.
My lord Leandro you shall to Valentia,
With our best thanks and greeting to the King;
His army's charge is ours, beside what else
We owe his royal bounty. Once more welcome
Alfonso now my father, witness I
Preserve my faith to my Rosania,
I hear the priest call us to other rites,
His altar doth expect another pair,
Make haste to light his tapers with thine eyes
And make our hearts each others sacrifice.

div.head: Epilogue, captain.
div.l: I am no epilogue, I come to pray
You'd tell me your opinion of the play,
Is the plot current? may we trust the wit
Without a say-master to authorise it?
Are the lines sterling? do they hold conceit?
And every piece with your allowance, weight?
That when you come abroad, you'll not report
You are sorry to have given white money for't?
So, so, I know your meaning, now pray tell
How did the action please ye, was it well?
How did King Stephen do, and tother prince?
Enough, enough, I apprehend, and since
I am at questions w'e, tell me faith
How do you like the captain? ha? he saith,
I'll tell you, you're my friends, none here, he knows,
I mean you o'the gentry, t'whom he owes
No money, will enter a false action,
And let the rest look to't, if there be one,
Among his city creditors, that dares,
He hath vowed to press, and send him to the wars.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
